Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Understanding Nanoscale Deformation by Characterizing the Mechanical Behavior of Nanoporous Noble Metals
Award.AbstractNarration: TECHNICAL: Nanoporous metals with nanoscale ligaments offer a unique opportunity to explore the deformation behavior of highly confined metallic volumes and understand the mechanisms that govern mechanical behavior at the nm length scale. A persistent problem exists in studies of nanocrystalline metals, thin films and nanostructured materials: what role do dislocations and other defects play in nanoscale deformation? It is understood that constraints on dislocation nucleation and motion arise as the available deformation volume decreases, but it is unclear whether dislocations are able to mediate plasticity in metal volumes that are several to tens of nm in size. Even if dislocations are involved in the deformation process, their behavior is likely to be heavily influenced by the presence of free surfaces and interfaces. Additional mechanisms such as diffusion may also occur. In order to correctly interpret and model the deformation behavior of nanocrystalline metals, we must understand the actual mechanisms that dominate deformation. The objectives of this CAREER research plan are to: (1) investigate nanoscale deformation behavior in nanoporous gold, palladium and iridium, using in situ transmission electron microscopy; (2) systematically study the mechanical properties of thin film and bulk nanoporous noble metals, and determine the appropriate scaling laws that describe these properties; (3) evaluate the damping behavior of nanoporous metals, which are expected to exhibit significantly higher damping and anelasticity versus dense or Ã¬m-scale porous metals. The intellectual merit of this project lies in its aim to uncover the fundamental mechanisms governing the mechanical behavior of nanoporous structures. The results from this project, which will focus on face-centered cubic noble metals, should be applicable to other nanoporous metals and relevant to the study of nanoscale materials subjected to deformation. NON-TECHNICAL: This study has a strong fundamental scientific basis, but will also benefit the application of nanoporous metals by enabling improvements in their mechanical stability. Additionally, by attaining a better understanding of the mechanical behavior of nanoporous structures, fellow scientists will be able to predict and tailor properties for a given application. The broader impact of this research will enhance the undergraduate education experience for materials engineers at the University of Kentucky, by providing them with a unique opportunity to study abroad and perform research in a world-leading materials laboratory in Germany. Both graduate and undergraduate students will be directly involved in this research. The engineering student exchange program between Kentucky and Karlsruhe is a continuing focus of the PI, who will recruit UK undergraduate students to work with graduate students and with visiting German students in his laboratory. This experience will provide UK undergraduates with international exposure and help them learn how to live and work in a global society. The results of this project will be presented at conferences and disseminated in the scientific literature, with joint authorship by each team of student researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this research project was to better understand the mechanical behavior of nanoporous noble metals, including gold, palladium and iridium. Nanoporous metals can be made from certain alloys, by using acid to selectively dissolve the more chemically active metal from the alloy. The more noble metal remains, initially as atoms or clusters on the receding alloy surface. Through surface diffusion, the noble metal atoms assemble into mounds to reduce their energy, thereby exposing new alloy surfaces from which the more chemically active metal is again removed. Through this continuous process, mounds elongate randomly and the alloy transforms into a three-dimensional network of open pores and interconnected ligaments, where pores and ligaments are on the order of 10 nanometers (see figure).

 

The small length scale of ligaments leads to novel mechanical behavior. There are two primary effects in nanoporous metals. As the dimensions of metal volumes decrease below the micron length scale, they exhibit higher strength because plastic (permanent) deformation is more difficult within the confined volume. Additionally, porosity typically lowers strength and stiffness (elastic modulus) of porous materials, as pores cannot carry loads.

 

One especially interesting aspect of nanoporous noble metals is the effect of this geometric structure on mechanical behavior. Consider gold, an extremely ductile metal that can be permanently deformed by extensive amounts, without fracturing. In nanoporous form, however, gold behaves in a brittle manner, easily cracking and fracturing when pulled in tension.

 

In order to predict the mechanical behavior, it is helpful to have so-called scaling laws that relate a given property of the porous metal to that of the corresponding fully dense metal. Such scaling laws exist for porous materials with pores and ligaments on the order of one micron or greater, and these describe well the behavior of porous materials made by methods such as foaming. However, those scaling laws are unable to properly describe strength, elasticity, and other mechanical properties of nanoporous metals.

 

Strength and elastic modulus are important mechanical properties for design purposes, as they determine the maximum loads and deflections for material structures under load. Accurate measurement of these properties for nanoporous gold has been difficult, due to its brittle behavior, and often was measured only in compression or using indirect techniques. In this project, however, we successfully measured these properties directly, using small-scale mechanical testing in tension (see figure), as well as compression. By fabricating samples that were free of all defects except for the pores themselves, we obtained the first values of strength and elastic modulus for nanoporous gold in tension. Importantly, these values were quite low compared to other groups’ results. However, we believe these values are correct, and can be understood through new scaling relations we developed.

 

A key outcome of this project is the scaling law we developed to describe the strength of nanoporous gold. This scaling law properly relates several different datasets: the strength values we measured in tension and compression; data from other researchers who used nanoindentation to indirectly measure strength; the strength of bulk, fully-dense gold; and finally, the strength of gold nanowires that were fabricated and tested by other research groups. Nanowire mechanical behavior is another exciting field of study, and our scaling relation provides a bridge between that field and nanoporous metals, thus broadening the impact of our research within the field of small-scale mechanical behavior.
